From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

Old Occitan

[edit]

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • enujar, enuejar

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Late Latin inodiāre.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /enoˈd͡ʒaɾ/

Verb

[edit]

enojar

  1. to bother, upset

Descendants

[edit]
  • Occitan: anujar, anutjar (Languedoc), einujar, einuiar (Limousin), enujar, enuiar (Provençal), enuiar (Vivaro-Alpine)
  • → Old Galician-Portuguese: anojar, enojar
    • Galician: anoxar
    • Portuguese: anojar, enjoar, enojar
  • → Old Spanish: enojar
    • Spanish: enojar

References

[edit]
  • DOM: enojar

Old Spanish

[edit]

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • enoyar (indigenous form)

Etymology

[edit]

Borrowed from Old Occitan enojar, from Late Latin inodiāre.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /enoˈʒaɾ/

Verb

[edit]

enojar

  1. to anger

Descendants

[edit]
  • Spanish: enojar

References

[edit]
  • Coromines, Joan; Pascual, José Antonio (1984), “enojar”, in Diccionario crítico etimológico castellano e hispánico [Critical Castilian and Hispanic etymological dictionary]‎[1] (in Spanish), volume II (Ce–F), Madrid: Gredos, →ISBN, page 635

Portuguese

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From Old Galician-Portuguese enojar (“to anger”), borrowed from Old Occitan enojar, from Vulgar Latin inodiāre (“make hateful”), from Latin odium (“hatred”). Compare ódio and enjoar.

Cognate with Catalan enutjar, Galician anoxar, Spanish enojar, Italian annoiare, French ennuyer and English annoy.

Pronunciation

[edit]
 
  • (Brazil) IPA(key): /e.noˈʒa(ʁ)/ [e.noˈʒa(h)]
  • (Brazil) IPA(key): /e.noˈʒa(ʁ)/ [e.noˈʒa(h)]
    • (São Paulo) IPA(key): /e.noˈʒa(ɾ)/
    • (Rio de Janeiro) IPA(key): /e.noˈʒa(ʁ)/ [e.noˈʒa(χ)]
    • (Southern Brazil) IPA(key): /e.noˈʒa(ɻ)/
 
  • (Portugal) IPA(key): /i.nuˈʒaɾ/
  • (Portugal) IPA(key): /i.nuˈʒaɾ/
    • (Southern Portugal) IPA(key): /i.nuˈʒa.ɾi/

  • Hyphenation: e‧no‧jar

Verb

[edit]

enojar (first-person singular present enojo, first-person singular preterite enojei, past participle enojado)

  1. to disgust (cause an intense dislike for something)
    Synonym: repugnar

Derived terms

[edit]
  • nojo

Spanish

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Old Spanish enojar, from Old Occitan enojar, from Late Latin inodiāre.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /enoˈxaɾ/ [e.noˈxaɾ]
  • Rhymes: -aɾ
  • Syllabification: e‧no‧jar

Verb

[edit]

enojar (first-person singular present enojo, first-person singular preterite enojé, past participle enojado) (less common in Spain)

  1. (transitive) to anger
  2. (reflexive) to become angry

Related terms

[edit]
  • desenojar
  • enojarse
